resources.string: Privacy
OctoApp does not collect any personalized information. I do not have any data about you, such as your email address. Even if you have an active subscription, you are completely anonymous.

All data collected is in the app\'s legitimate interest. If you have any questions, please reach out to hello@octoapp.eu

Data privacy statement

OctoApp is an open source project.
Anonymous crash reporting

If enabled, OctoApp sends automated crash reports to Firebase Crashlytics, helping me make the app stable for all users and devices. These reports are anonymous and deleted after 90 days. They contain generic information about your device, such as the model or Android version and the most recent logs collected by the app. Crash reports do not contain any sensitive data as all API keys, host names or Basic Auth credentials are scrubbed (best effort) when any error is created and again before the logs are cached.
Anonymous usage statistics

If enabled, OctoApp sends anonymous usage information to Firebase Analytics which will be deleted after 90 days. This information helps me in determining which features of the app are used the most, and where I should spend time on improving to benefit users. This information does not contain any data except which features of the app are used and basic information about your setup, such as which plugins are installed or the OctoPrint version. The data is not linked to any advertisement profile or anything similar. If you reinstall the app or switch your device, I do not have any means to connect your data.
Can\'t resolve %s
This indicates a configuration issue. The phone can\'t resolve a IP address for %s, this is not influenced by any OctoPrint settings or the API key.
Host %s is not reachable
This indicates a configuration issue. The phone can\'t reach %s, this is not influenced by any OctoPrint settings or the API key.
Can connect to %1$s but not to port %2$d
The phone can connect to the host, but the port %d does not accept incoming connections.
Can connect but received %d instead of 200
The app was able to establish a connection to %s, but the server did not respond as expected.
Can\'t connect because of an error
A unexpected error occurred while trying to connect to %1$s (%2$s)
Basic Authentication required
Please enter your Basic Auth credentials below, not your OctoPrint user and password.
Unable to resolve **%s**

Android is not able to resolve the IP address for **%1$s**. Check following things to resolve the issue:

- Ensure there is no typo
- Make sure you are connected to the internet
- Make sure you are on the correct WiFi network
- Try to open [%2$s](%2$s) in your browser
- Try using the **IP address** instead of **%1$s**
Unable to resolve **%s**

Android is not able to resolve the IP address for **%1$s**. Android devices are sometimes configured by the manufacturer in a way that they cannot reliably resolve .home or .local domains. Check following things to resolve the issue:

- Ensure there is no typo
- Make sure you are on the correct WiFi network
- Try to open [%2$s](%2$s) in your browser
- Try using the **IP address** instead of **%1$s**
Unable to connect to **%s**

OctoApp resolved the IP of **%1$s**, but **%2$s** can't be reached within 2 seconds. Check following things to resolve the issue:

- Make sure the machine hosting OctoPrint is turned on and connected
- If your OctoPrint is only available locally, make sure you are connected to the correct WiFi network
- Try to open [%3$s](%3$s) in your browser
Android does not trust **%s**

The SSL certificate presented by your OctoPrint can not be used to establish a HTTPS connection because Android does not trust the certificate. This is a common issue for self-signed certificates that were not installed on this phone.

Additionally, the certificate uses a deprecated format that does not comply to modern security standards. A "subject alternative name" (SAN) field is required from Android 9 onwards.

OctoApp can add this certificate to a trusted list and will bypass Androidâ€™s check for this certificate.

The SSL certificate presented by your OctoPrint can not be used to establish a HTTPS connection because Android does not trust the certificate. This is a common issue for self-signed certificates that were not installed on this phone.\n\nOctoApp can add this certificate to a trusted list and will bypass Androidâ€™s check for this certificate.
URL syntax error
The URL **%1$s** seems to contain a syntax error and can\'t be parsed. Android reports following error:\n\n**%2$s**
OctoPrint not found

OctoApp was able to connect to **%1$s** but received a 404 response. Check following things to resolve the issue:

- Make sure you use the correct port and host

- Make sure that you use the correct path in the URL

- Try to open [%1$s](**%1$s**) in your browser
Connected to **%1$s** but port **%2$d** is closed

OctoApp was able to connect to **%1$s** but port **%2$d** is closed. Check following things to resolve the issue:


- Make sure **%2$d** is correct. If you don't specify the port explicitly, OctoApp will use 80 for HTTP and 443 for HTTPS

- Try to open [%3$s](%3$s) in your browser
Failed to connect to **%s** via HTTP

OctoApp was able to communicate with **%1$s**, but when trying to establish a HTTP(S) connection an unexpected error occurred. Android reports following issue:

**%2$s**

You can **long-press "Need help?"** above to get support (please include logs).
Unexpected issue

OctoApp encountered an unexpected error. Android reports following issue:

**%1$s**

You can **long-press "Need help?"** above to get support (please include logs).
**%s** might not be an OctoPrint
OctoApp was able to communicate with **%1$s**, but the server seems not to be a recent version of OctoPrint.\n\nYou can continue, but other issues may arise in the following steps.
HTTP access to **%s** works, but web socket broken

OctoApp can communicate with **%1$s**, but the web socket failed to connect with response code **%2$d**. This is a very common issue with incorrectly configured reverse proxy setups. Check following things to resolve the issue:

- Make sure your proxy sets the `Upgrade: WebSocket` header for `%3$s` as it is not forwarded to OctoPrint by default
- Refer to the [configuration examples in the OctoPrint community](https://community.octoprint.org/t/reverse-proxy-configuration-examples/1107) for Nginx, HAProxy, Apache and others

I speak English and German. My current local time is %1$s (%2$s).
OctoApp Lab
Here you can find experimental settings and things I do not officially support but which you can use at your own will. Features might be removed without prior notice.
Notification battery saver

With version 1.8, I introduced a battery saving mechanic for the print notification as it was consuming a lot of power on some devices. You can disable it to return to the old behaviour. This might resolve issues with missing filament change notifications.
Allow OctoApp to rotate
OctoApp can rotate into landscape mode. The UI is not optimized and rotating might cause issues on some screens. Will take affect after restart.
New webcam stack
Completely new webcam implementation introduced with version 1.9.0. The new webcam stack is using less resources and has a lower latency. Will take affect after a restart.
